Scientists previously thought Oahu was the remnant of Wai'anae and Ko'olau .

Lead author John Sinton said in a statement : Both of these assumptions can now be revised : Wai'anae is not as large as previously thought and Ka'ena Volcano formed in the region between Kaua'i and Wai'anae .
In 2010 , scientists found unusual lavas from Wai'anae .

Researchers found that data relating to the age , geochemistry and geological observations of Ka - ena showed it was not part of Wai'anae , but an earlier volcanic structure , which Wai'anae was built on .

What is particularly interesting is that Ka'ena appears to have had an unusually prolonged history as a submarine volcano , only breaching the ocean surface very late in its history , Sinton said in a statement .
